commentBody: Great "aha" moment, well done!!

This felt hard while I was doing it because I couldn't figure out the theme, but ended up finishing pretty quick for a Thursday. I finally got it when I saw the nice little pictures. It was definitely easier than yesterday for me.

I had never heard of JOHDPURS, it's nice to learn a new word.
I can feel the anger of those who hate rebus puzzles boiling up from miles away.
Never heard of jodphurs. Might never again either.

Nice to see David put in an appearance 
with a very David Steinberg Thursday offering. 

I hope U were up for it!

Jodphurs eh? 

All right then.

This is the first time I've ever had to spell JODHPURS, and I got it wrong. I've read it multiple times, I'm sure we all have, but I've never written it down  before. Not often I get many firsts at my age. 
Oh, and fun puzzle too. Love the graphics, they nicely revealed the theme which I had entirely missed. (I've had better days...)

Cute puzzle, but I had the same trouble with it that I do a lot of rebuses, which is that it bugs me to have the U in the across clue just replaced with something that doesn't really make sense until the little graphics kicked in. I think I'm just too literal-minded sometimes.

I really must remember how to spell jodhpurs. I wore them often enough growing up horseback riding.  The h/p sequence always trips me up and certainly lost me a bit of solving time here. No matter. It was a marvelous puzzle and a real rush when you realize you've been putting items in your pants pockets.

Maybe things have changed since I was in the Army, but when I was in uniform, the mess was where you ate; what you ate was "chow" or "Army food." Particular recurring items had their own names, such as "SOS" for chipped beef on toast. Also, elemental sulfur is odorless; the stinky stuff is sulfur compounds such as mercaptan and hydrogen sulfide.

At long last, this puzzle reveals the reason behind one of the incomprehensible irritating features of some store-bought clothing:

LADIES’ PANTS:  no pockets!!!
That was fun. Thanks :)
I really enjoyed this one after I figured out how 8D worked. Bravo!
I'll never remember. In the rebus space, are the across and down components separated by a hyphen or a slash?
Yay, I'm glad of Mr Steinberg's semiretirement. Welcome back.
Swing and a miss for me, personally. Though I did learn that JODHPURS are a thing. I stared at that for several minutes wondering what I’d messed up, lol.
This is the most fun I've had solving a crossword in a long time! Thanks!

When I got the idea of the trick, I just treated the letter U as a pocket holding the thing in the clue, and it worked fine. No elaborate rebus-entry required. I guess it was a kind of rebus, but I just thought of it as a cool Thursday twist.
Ok well.  Better that yesterday I guess.  But who keeps gloves in their jeans pockets?  Must be small gloves, I guess.
I’ll put myself on record for loving rebus puzzles—and anything tricky! This was one a charmer.
That was very satisfying. I got the theme with MICKEY and the rest followed from there.

I’d never heard of Oshea Jackson Jr and I didn’t figure out the theme ahead of time so the O in OSHEA was a flat out guess.  I was surprised to get the happy music. Oddly JODHPURS wasn’t a problem. 
Even though I never got the theme ahead of time, in retrospect I really liked it.

Ingenious puzzle, its construction must have been a pleasure. Happy cluing. The theme, once you figured it out, lost a little of its "aha" vibe each time, but there was much joy and liveliness about the whole affair that the easiness is more like breeziness, in the best sense of being uplifting. What a puzzle should do: lift spirits. Fete accompli!

This puzzle is sibilant with esses. An astonishing number of plurals, plus words like sass and oasis, let alone "says so." If Louis, that old poppa-doppler or whatever he calls himself, can enlighten us, or some other logotician, as to which puzzles had the most esses ever, I'd bet this would be in the top ten. 

Great to have Jason MOMoa and teen DADs in this puzzle. Maybe a little wave from the constructor to his family, which, if I remember, were all great puzzlemakers, like our version of the Flying Wallendas. Well I'm glad Mr. Steinberg is still willing to griddle one up for us. A nice little pick-me-up after another day smelling the odor of sulphur reek ever more pungently. Who's in whose pocket?
Excellent puzzle. Very fair.
Such a clever and delightful puzzle! Thank you, Mr. Steinberg!

JODHPURS - Finally a word to rhyme with CLOTBURS!

(Comment intended for longtime Wordplay commenters.)
Ooh! A extra little dopamine hit after the music! We get to see what's in those pockets! What a fun puzzle.
Wow this was about as tight a theme as you can have! I love that it took me awhile to figure it out but once I did it was delightful. Well done!

What a clever twist on the use of a pocket 😆 I took a different approach to this once I saw the clue for 35A. I entered “U” at the intersection of each theme clue. That helped me identify what each type of pants I was looking for and essentially “solved” the puzzle for me. What I didn’t get the chance to do was go back and insert was the other portion of the rebus answers for all of the down clued intersecting answers. Since the U was one of the parts of the rebus, I didn’t get that chance, but I knew what they were supposed to be, so I’m glad I at least figured it out before the animation arrived. Thank you, David, for another wonderful construction. The puzzle gene runs strong in your family!!
Love to see David Steinberg back.  28 seems a bit old for semi-retirement, but I’m glad we can hope for some more puzzles from the old geezer.
Fun

Having never tried my hand at crossword construction, I imagine one of the most challenging aspects is coming up with a novel clue for evergreen words like EPEE, ERA, and so forth. With that in mind, a major tip of the cap to the constructor for the clue Deb mentioned - [Watches or Matches] solving to SEES was absolutely brilliant.

Sorry, this was way too easy and I found the theme overwrought and awkward.  Having the actual fill word simply spelled out (rather than clued) in each paired clue made the whole thing worse.

Give us back the likes of yesterday's please.  It was smoother, more clever, harder, and a lot more fun.  (For me.)

I appreciate the effort and that each pants type happened to have a U in it, but....

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

The theme was ok, but it was too easy for a Thursday and there were too many black squares. 

5/10

This was brilliant, I thought, as  finished the puzzle.
That's when I went to the byline.
But of course - David Steinberg!

Genius idea and what a great ride this was.
............................................

Another great ride was the 1996 JETTA manual VR6 I used to have. Many good memories of driving it, but for one:
 
I was crossing a Portland bridge at night, when suddenly I saw one single headlamp in the rearview, coming at me at the speed of light. 
I got so spooked that I stepped on it to get to the other side and onto the highway as fast as I could, where I intended to let the crazed motorcyclist hopefully pass me by and be on his way.
When I got on the highway, he got on the same lane and came up right behind me!
 
And that's when it came on, that darned red light spinning round and round.
I pulled over.
"Why were you speeding?"
"Because I was being chased! Oh. Wait. That didn't come out right, officer. Sir. Um. Uh. Let me explain..."

.............................................
Thank you, David, for a fabulous puzzle. 
Please don't stay away too long!

I quite liked this puzzle! As someone who'd consider myself a beginner, I agree with other comments in that it was easier than a lot of other Thursday puzzles, but one of a few that I've managed to solve with no help at all. Very fun.
This was a really good one. I’m gonna show JODPHURS to everyone in the Connections chat complaining that these games are too American-centric.

I was a little disappointed with this one.  I hopped around the grid and got POCKETS early which made those squares giveaways. The rest just felt like a lot of little answers. I did like seeing JODHPURS in a puzzle.

Need a jodhpurs smile?  There's always Groucho -

Hooray for Capt. Spaulding,
The African explorer.
Some people call him schnorrer. 
Hurray! Hurray! Hurray!
Doable Thursday.  Almost Wednesday Trad level.

I enjoyed the puzzle, but as someone who had never heard of JODHPURS, that clue left me baffled. Perhaps the clue of 37A: "Stick in a bucket?" didn't need the question mark because that encouraged me to make a less obvious choice. And 62A: "Apt surname for Scarlett" had me convinced it was ROSE until I finally wised up on the cross clues. So, overall, a great Thursday puzzle.
Sorry. Absolutely hated today's puzzle. Double rebus...nope.

I didn't get them all, but this puzzle was delightful. I kept thinking that the revealer was "accents" and then nothing fit there. I kept trying to figure out where an accent would go in each of the words with the Us in them. What a merry romp I had around that puzzle!

Would love to carry it in my Us.
Welp, lost my 18 day streak. JODHPURS was new by me, and I had TArT for delicacy, so brute forcing for the J was to no avail. Also tried bOYlE and dOYlE

Today would have been easy and fun except I chose the hard way 😖. Since reviewing my answers netted no errors (I thought), I focused on the rebus. For several stressful minutes I toggled U, U/PEN and PEN, etc.  It turns out I misspelled MOMOA and had not even looked at ROO 🤦🏾‍♀️!

Somehow, I still ended up 3:57 faster than my average Thursday speed. Streak is intact. No look-ups! Pretty fun.

Without my blunder, the puzzle was otherwise a breeze.  For those of you who are wondering, OSHEA Jackson, Jr. is Ice Cube’s son.  The constructor’s addition of “Jr.” was superfluous since Ice Cube is OSHEA Jackson (Sr.).

Note DMS in 1D. I had to slide that into my comment 😜.

It’s going to be gray and dreary here today and part of tomorrow but it’s almost Carnival Time 💃🏾! Wish me luck in not missing any days on here during this — ahem — *hectic* time 🥴🤕🍸.

For some reason it never occurred to me to fill in those squares with a "rebus." Fortunately, it wasn't required. Autocheck accepted the letters from the Across fills as being enough. I read "MICU" as MICKEY, but didn't write it. The same with PERSE(PHONE) on my CORDUROYS. Had it not been for those two, I might never have understood that GOTOU was GOT O(pen) and I had never heard of BI(G LOVE) before tonight and ended up googling "biglove" to try to figure out what was going on. I'm glad google knew, although it wasn't necessary in order to get the music. In fact, the red glove was already showing in its square before I turned to googling.
Can I just give it a yelp rating of 1 and move on ?
This was a fun, clever Thursday! I very much enjoyed, though I must say, I was shocked when JODHPURS actually went through (after checking the cross-entries about 15 times)

"Wait, where do I put my keys in these pants?"
"Come on, it's not pocket science."

(These puns are jean-ius.)

JODHPURS! I knew the word, but was not sure of the spelling. I figured it must be either JHODPURS or JOHDPURS, so filled in J__DPURS. OOPS!  Caused me some trouble in that area. At least I didn’t consider JODPHURS (a misspelling that seems quite common based on the comments).

While I could marvel at the concept, I couldn’t conceptualize two of the rebuses even though I completed the puzzle. As always, I am not a fan of pop trivia, and of course that was the obstacle once again.

After struggling through yesterday (12:50 slower than my average), I was delighted to catch the gimmick and breeze through this one (15:33 faster than my average). Fun, easy solve… though it does rather feel like it and Wednesday’s should’ve been swapped!

Oh wow, I did this without lookups and in 17 minutes, too (that is, Wednesday time) - this would never have happened a year ago, when I was stumped by almost any Thursday puzzle. It's nice to see I'm making progress.

That was a neat trick - however, even though my grid is filled and I see the graphics, I still don't understand the sports thing or know the title of that HBO show: I entered U/[down ending] rebuses in the other themed squares but in these two cases I got away with just the U. Had the theme been implemented differently - for example, requiring rebuses in all squares, I would probably have failed to complete the puzzle.

Brilliantly conceived, though that’s par for the course for David Steinberg. 

Ahh, BIG LOVE next to TABERNACLE: well played, David, well played. As someone who grew up at the mouth of Big Cottonwood canyon, I came of age—literally, geographically—smack dab between the two.

Nice to see David Steinberg’s name on a puzzle! It was much quicker than the average Thursday for me, but part of that is that for once l just put the “U” in the rebus squares, since I wasn’t sure immediately what was going on. It was fun to see the little pictures emerge! The show I remembered was “Sister Wives”, so I almost got dooked on “Big Love”! 🤦🏻‍♀️ Since jodhpurs were common apparel in my horseback riding youth, I was surprised that so many were unfamiliar with the term— though I must concede the spelling does look a bit funky!

I'm looking at it.

Solved.

On my screen.

I still don't get it.

Strands Thread:


Strands #361
“Living large”
🔵🟡🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵🔵

Please expand no thoughts of posting a spoiler until after the View All Replies button.

A clever title makes all the difference.
Great puzzle, lots of fun. Loved the 'pocket' angle!
I loved the graphics showing up when solved.  Like others always pleased to see David’s name as the constructor.  What a fun Thursday puzzle.
Loved this delightful puzzle!

So fun! Thank you for a terrific start to the day. The Zamboni a while back was the tops, but the little graphics in this one are so great, even if only viewable on one’s PERSE-PHONE. And who doesn’t love pockets—especially in dresses and skirts? Ralph Lauren has definitely made JODHPURS part of the American vernacular.
Cute cute cute. Loved it. I have never considered the spelling of JODHPURS before today but would never have guessed accurately if asked!
Lovely, breezy solve! Persephone was a dead giveaway for the theme, finished well under my Thursday average (thanks to a couple of hints from my partner). Thanks!

Random thoughts.
Any puzzle with ROO and Jason MOMOA in it is okay by me.

I solved the puzzle without realizing it was a double rebus, because the revealer told me to put Us into the rebus squares, and I never had a chance to figure out the down clues. Not sure how I feel about that, though I did have fun while solving. 

I worked in downtown Manhattan for 30+ years. Wednesday was the anniversary of the first attack on the WTC, and I still have a reaction when I see a RYDER truck. (Apologies for injecting reality into my puzzle comments.)
They say on this puzzle for two years? From David Steinberg? I got excited just seeing his name. Brilliant. Loved it.

David, it always makes me happy to see your constructor byline. I enjoyed figuring out how the pockets worked. I regret that I solved this while half awake after a longish day of skiing, as I don’t think I fully appreciated your puzzle’s charm. 

Deb, it *is* an elegant touch that the only U’s in the grid are the pockets. But from my Scrabble-playing experience, I would argue that U is the most useless vowel in English. It’s not unusual for me to get stuck with one at the end of a game. 

Thanks, y’all!

For anyone who is just learning the word JODHPURS, do yourself a favor and se “Sunset Boulevard.” It’s an absolutely fantastic movie that well deserves its place in the Hollywood canon. Bonus points for a hunky young William Holden. 

Towards the end, watch for the director Cecil B. DeMille playing himself. He’s wearing jodhpurs.
What a perfect Thursday puzzle, so clever! The visual reveals at the end were a nice surprise, too!

Nice challenging Thursday. Not all that easy for me, of course, and I made it a little tougher by having to re-ponder the trick for each of the rebus squares. That's my memory. Oh, and I'm glad to see that at least I'm not the only one who was unfamiliar with JODHPURS. Really different puzzle find today. Theme was definitely in the vicinity of dad jokes. Anyway - a Sunday from December 28, 2003 by Seth A. Abel with the title: Headlines that make you go "Huh?" All the theme clues started with "Ambiguous headline about..." A couple of examples: ...about agricultural legislation: FARMERBILLDIESINHOUSE ...about construction delay : REDTAPEHOLDSUPBRIDGE ...about the Bush cabinet : ONEILLISFEDSECRETARY And my favorite answer: COPSHELPDOGBITEVICTIM And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/28/2003&g=79&d=A I'm done. ....

It's not that these crosswords are too difficult, there's just so much local knowledge that it's getting frustrating. Maybe this type of crossword is not for me. 

There were so many clues I would never know in the top half  that I decided just to reveal them, and just solve what I see as 'real' crossword clues! MOMOA, CENA, OSHEA, MESSES, SALT LAKE radio, then later - how do you ROAST in a slow cooker? Isn't it  stewing?

But not knowing 'shook one's defender' or what it meant, I assumed GOTOU must be the answer, and not knowing the HBO show I thought BIU must be the answer. Forgot the Greek goddesses name. Micu Mouse? Another US show I didn't know. 
So I had no clue rebuses were involved. 
I solved all the trousers clues and had no idea what POCKETS implied, and when I finished lo and behold the little pictures appeared. 
Sigh.
PS The word JODHPURS comes from Hindi and was always in our spelling tests!

Great fun! As usual I didn’t understand the theme until very late. But the various pants were discoverable, and eventually … ta da!

This one truly is elegant.
Quality Thursday puzzle! Well done.

The thing that's interesting here is that there happen to be four words for "pants" that all have about the same number of letters, each with a U in the middle. Bravo to the constructor for realizing this!

JODHPURS was a cinch for me, but I learned the word from my father, who was born during the Harding administration. I tend to associate them with one particular person, who I won't mention, because I don't want someone bringing up Godwin's Law.

The amusing sad thing is that it was TROUSERS that I got stuck on, trying for a couple of minutes to somehow jam CARPENTERS in there, even though that didn't really make any sense

I’m not a fan of visual themes that are too cute by half. I thought the cluing was interesting and some of the answers were pretty good. But I think you should have a decent chance of solving the theme before solving the puzzle and not relying on sight gags to get it. That’s not a crossword, that’s a rebus

First of all, welcome back David Steinberg.  It was so nice to see your name this morning.

I thought this was a delightful puzzle. In my print version, I didn't draw the pictures, just wrote the words in the pocket.  When I later saw how cute the graphics on xwordinfo were, I kind of wish I did it that way. 

It's a shame that people who solve on the app could have completed the puzzle with just the U's and gotten credit for a successfully completed puzzle.  That would be missing the point.
The true brooding genre: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chick_lit
I see re-education is going well.  DMS was clued in the suggested manner and RAT made no mention of me.

Clever, but preciously clever, imo. The theme clues imply a connection where there is none. Bluejeans have no inherent relationship with gloves; indeed, one may carry a glove (did we lose the other one?) or a key, phone or pen in a pocket of bluejeans. Which is the case for all the pants used, of course. It's not like there's a hidden lightbulb moment awaiting a solver where they say to themselves, "Aha, great clue! Yes, it's the genius of jodhpur design that makes them so ideal for carrying keys!".

Now if I could just remember where I put my phone corduroys, I could get dressed and start my day...

Whereas yesterday the tricky theme tripped me up, today I got it right away 🤣 as soon as PERSE was all that fit for PERSEPHONE I knew something was up! Loved the fillers, I enjoy clever word play vs trivia when it comes to those tricky corners with only a few crosses. 

I guess you can say that I've got one hand in my pocket and the others doing the crossword ✌🏻✌🏻✌🏻

It’s just the inconsistency that makes rebus puzzles frustrating. I got the theme quickly, but just leaving the U in place to match the across wasn’t good enough this time. In other rebus puzzles it would have been.

Hee-hee!

Yesterday, my archive find was a 
David Steinberg Friday puzzle from 2015,
and I woke to a fresh-as-a-daisy
Steinberg Thursday.

So SASSy!

With a fun graphic!
After Wednesday’s lloonngg fun!
Two days, two little digital gifts.

I never thought to add anything 
to the U squares, 
so it was quick and so *very* satisfying.

Happy Thursday all!
The Friday of Fridays!
25 Down --- Bill Cosby, 1964!  I was about 10 when I heard it.
Two years in the slow cooker yielded this tasty treat (the BEEF would not have held up so well).  Hide the rebus in the clue in plain sight = brilliant.  Many thanks.
Great puzzle! Just the right amount of trickiness without pushing into frustration. No look-ups needed except consulting with my sports fan husband on 4 Down.
Now that was fun.
Everything went well until I got stumped by the TWIG ROMA OOPS box. Not a RUBY tomato. Not OH MY or OH NO, though I suspected OOPS too. Sigh.
Somehow I did this puzzle without lookups, in a reasonable amount of time, and without ever figuring out the rebus aspect.

How is this a theme? I could literally put 1,000,001 different things in my pocket. I cleared this in 13 minutes with complete disregard for the theme.
8D is the worst - somehow the solvers should know a random show from 20 years ago with nothing but BI??? without any crosses to help.
Brilliant, really. For such difficult restrictions (pants that have a U) the puzzle was amazingly clean and simple -- with the possible exception of "tell of," which seemed a bit awkward.

I was buoyant after coursing through this high-quality feel-good creation.

OMG-SO-CLEVER.  
•	Coming up with the idea that the letter U can represent a pocket.  Where did that come from?  Genius!
•	Going from that to a puzzle whose theme is items in pants.  What a leap!

HOW-DID-HE-DO-THAT?
•	Finding four types of pants that not only contain the letter U, but contain lengths that fit the requirements of symmetry.
•	I don’t ever remember a rebuts puzzle where I didn’t actually have to write the rebus or its first letter in, where I could simply imagine it. Is that not expanding the envelope or what?

Plus, a grid so junk-free that it makes me calm just to look at it. Sweet cluing – I loved being misdirected by [Matches or watches], where I was thinking nouns, not verbs (Hi, @Deb!).

And lovely serendipities. A backward SERA, echoing that answer from yesterday’s puzzle. The cross of WOO and a backward AMOR.

Not only was I buoyant after solving, but I will be buoyant again when I see your name atop a puzzle, David.  Thank you for a splendid outing!

Shaking my head at how many times I saw “mirror image” before the mirage cleared. Has my visual cortex been corrupted by too much wordplay?

A lot of pocketsize words jammed into this one.
But fun to do.
Cute! I like a cute idea.

Annoying!
Had puzzle finished, but still not correct.
Read the column and went back and put in the rebuses.
Still incorrect.
Fixed one letter (typo).
Still not correct.
Went back. Removed the slashes I had put in for the rebus boxes.
Still not correct.
Went back again.  Gave up my over 100 day streak and let it check for me.
Rebus boxes were the issue.
Went in, removed everything except the "U" and finally correct.

I really hate rebuses and this is why.
Another one of those puzzzles I solved quite easily and don't give a hoot about what the editor found so charming. Note to self: Thursdays are annoying.
I solved the Thursday puzzle correctly on my iPad, but, because of formatting issues, I did not get credit, and my streak was interrupted.  How can I get my streak back?
The puzzle was fine. On Android there's a programming issue in that the puzzle is only considered finished *without* the rebus answers. Which kind of defeats the purpose of the rebus.

Thanks to the editors for 
Wednesday and Thursday 
rebus puzzles, 
neither of which 
called for squishing 
more than one letter 
into a square.
I already knew that Beijing is larger than "Little Rhody" but TIL that Juneau is as well. Way bigger.
The pun on “U may carry” was great

Gee whiz!  Am I late?  It's not quite 8 a.m., but I see the villagers are out with their pitchforks and scythes....or maybe not.  I shouldn't assume that this SuperStumper has aroused ire....but then, it IS David Steinberg.  (We knew you couldn't stay away!)

Aside from the struggle to remember how to spell JOHDPURS, this wasn't a difficult puzzle, except where....well, U know.

I wanted CERES instead of ...

And while I was still  in Stumperville, I thought about LOCKERS, LOCKETS, COCKERS, COOKERS, COOKIES (I was getting desperate)....and then I went back to my earliest suspicion (because I start puzzles at the bottom) and MICKEY Mouse gave me a wink (and a smirk, too, I believe.)

Wonderful way to start my Thursday, Whippersnapper!

I'm reminded of the theme we had on Tuesday (crystal, dial, hands, case), since I was recently reading about the tiny “fifth pocket” on BLUE JEANS, the one inside the actual right side pocket. As designed by Levi Strauss over 150 years ago it was originally intended to hold a POCKET WATCH, and retained even when that item became outdated. I love that little pocket, and sometimes use it to stash a few coins. 

Fun theme. I like that we had cool graphics two days in a row. 
My final correction was changing a SCArY snake into a SCALY one.

Wonderful puzzle!

I take my hat off -- and pull my POCKETS out -- to puzzle maker, David Steinberg.

I think it would be difficult enough to come up with four kinds of pants that have a U in them.  And then to structure the puzzle in such a way that each U can hold something that we actually put in our pockets.
So clever!

Can't get enough of Mr. Steinberg.  Make us another one soon!

Another great Thursday puzzle!

The only problem I had with it is there were no mentions of Bilbo, Gollum and the Ring.

Wow! I admit I found the grid construction a little awkward at first glance, but I had faith that the theme would be good enough to justify it. I was right! Very, very cool. I always open a Thursday puzzle hoping to have my brain melted like this.

That was really enjoyable! I was on the wrong track for a while thinking the gimmick was a direction change with the vertical answers continuing on with the horizontal squares, so that slowed me down. I then had TELLON for 40A for too long, and tried mightily to make BEANROASTS a thing with some creative tailoring for those POCKATS.

Really enjoyed the variety of the consecutive rebus puzzles from yesterday and today!

I didn't find the theme all that clever mainly because the "pocket" answers were not at all unique to the type of pants. Why do gloves belong in blue jeans? Why a phone in corduroys? Seemed ambiguous. 

Unrelated, but this is the first time I've ever heard or seen the word "jodhpurs." I was sure I had a clue wrong lol.

Loved this puzzle, thanks, David.

JODHPURS was a total gimme for me.
Dunno if that is age or wheelhouse.

Tight theme, the only other clothing items I can think of with Us and pockets --- culottes and jumpsuits.

So, the puzzle was good, not too chewy, but I was totally stumped on where the rebus/turn should go. I resorted to Deb for help and only then understood nothing beyond the U was required. 
Sure, the graphics in completion are cute. But did I miss something? It felt like completing in the dark until the end. 
Perhaps I’m just too weary to get my head round it today, been a tough week. I get that KEY, PHONE GLOVE are the clues, but without recourse to entering them somewhere it felt off.
Two self-indulgent gimmicks in a row. Ugh. Zero stars.
Nice Thursday puzzle. Thank you.

Cute Thursday puzzle. Solved it in 20 minutes, so faster for me than yesterday's.

Thank goodness I knew who wrote "Dubliners", since I am completely unfamiliar with JODHPURS. Quite the potential Natick there ... perhaps.

No way I can fit a glove in a pocket of my BLUEJEANS, and I'd never carry a pen in my TROUSERS, but ... it's a puzzle!

Enjoyed this one, though I wonder what other commenters thought.
somebody help here. i've tried just putting u in the square, just the rebus, both the u and rebus. hate it when i know the answer, but just can't figure out how to enter it.

Managed to finish this puzzle with only one peek at the answer key. After I let go of "smoky" for 17A and "pwn" for 28A, it went smoothly.

Did not finish yesterday's puzzle, but may try again now that I know there are rebi.

This was an OK puzzle -- just filled in words and tried to ignore the whole "Capital U equals pocket" info. Filled in what I could of 35D, and thought that maybe there was a variation on the classical name.

This puzzle had one reference to a TV show I have never seen (nor had any desire to). It was possible to work around that. But yesterday's Strands was totally opaque. I had to use six hints (a personal record!), and still could not figure out the theme till the very end. (Fire is life? Hinduism?) Very frustrating for the two of us in the NYT puzzle-solving group who know nothing about that show (and care less).

Oh well, enough kvetching. Nice puzzle.

Wow! Solved without going to the Wordplay column for a hint. 🏆 
That moment when I figured out the Us... Fun!

In Hindi, there is a different letter for a different sound:
D and DH are how we write two different Hindi letters when using the Roman alphabet. Dharma is a five-letter word, because “dh” is a single letter.
T/TH, B/BH. Buddha is B-u-d-dh-a. Siddhartha is S-i-d-dh-a-r-th-a. Gandhi is G-a-n-dh-i.

This is a common thing when transcribing letters from other alphabets:
Hebrew: חַלָּה, challah (bread) distinguishes the letter CH from the letter H, which are both distinct single letters in Hebrew.
Ukrainian / Russian: борщ, borshch/borscht (soup) uses the four letters shch to denote the sound of the single letter щ in Roman spelling. Polish uses a different four letters for the same: szcz.

The letter H is always brought in to show aspiration or affrication - breath complications, softenings. So T contrasts with TH, S with SH, D with DH, B with BH, etc.

Jodhpur(s) is an ordinary word to horse folks and fashionistas. Reading it, even for the first time, understand that the H belongs to and softens the D, and has nothing to do with the P in the next syllable.

Dave,

It is definitely a rebus puzzle, 
in the classic meaning of the word rebus, 
and the only meaning outside Crosslandia. 

The U's are POCKETS that contain objects 
(which do not need to named in the grid, 
since they're already named in the clues).

It is not a puzzle that requires squishing 
more than one letter into a square.

Yesterday's puzzle was also a rebus
that did not require squishing.

@Barry Ancona

Classic definition:

   A representation of words or
   syllables by pictures of objects
   or by symbols whose names 
   resemble the intended words
   or syllables in sound

By that definition, the top rebus would be "you glove" or "glove you", which isn't the case.

It's just a crossword-style rebus.
